ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Different genres of Japanese music from the late 19th-early 20th century to roughly present-day.
I learned about the history of music in Japan.
I learned a lot of interesting things about the history of music in Japan across many time periods.
Learned about a breadth of Japanese music of the last century (and a bit from earlier) as well as various influences and cultural forces involved
We learned about Japanese music starting from  idol music to older war music.
I learned lots about different types of music in Japan, ranging from popular music to gagaku.
I learned about various genres of Japanese music and was able to make comparisons to Western music in various scenarios.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Lectures were engaging with different materials/sources (music videos, documents). Though music theory was discussed, prior knowledge wasn't required and application/discussion wasn't isolating.
Weaknesses: Backwards chronological order was the intention but it started to go all over the place towards the end. Understandable, as music chronology is difficult to track, but it can get confusing.
The class was wonderful. I love music. I struggle with essays, though...

Many class periods felt like interesting show-and-tell periods rather than lectures of trying to get through a certain amount of content, which could be seen either as a strength or weakness. I felt like a lot of the stuff was mine to learn, and I got to decide what things I wanted to look more into, and what things I wanted to write my essays about (again, could be both strength and weakness).
Course works well as a once-a-week thing and I appreciate the low workload but it would be nice to have maybe a listening list to keep us engaged over the weekend the weeks we don't have assignments

Strengths: Lots and lots of new topics!
Weaknesses: Sometimes it got a bit wordy and technical in music theory, which was cool to hear about but sometimes went over my head a bit.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you're interested in what the title says (Music in Japan). You get what you signed up for but if you didn't sign up for that...don't really know what to tell you.
I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in the history of music and Japan.

Depends, I think this class both attracts and is also suited for a very specific set of students. A lot of people come in interested in the more recent forms of Japanese music, but this class goes further back, and I can see how it might sometimes feel boring to those who aren't really interested in the history of Japanese music.

Yes! If you're interested in learning more about Japanese music, regardless of era. Mostly, the class tended to focus on more traditional, historic elements of Japanese music which was unexpected but welcome.
Yes, if you have any interest in Japanese music from any angle (classical, video games, jpop, wartime etc) this is a perfect course to take. The roundtable open discussions are great!
Yes if they are interested in Japanese music and culture.
Yes! It is such an interesting writing credit and extremely enjoyable.

The course has some very interesting topics and we get to listen to, and write about a lot of different kinds of music. If you are looking for a fun writing seminar, or just want to learn more about Japanese Music, this is a good course to take.
